title: 106_hr1625
content: The "Human Rights Information Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section highlights key points related to human rights. Congress finds that the national and international protection of human rights is a fundamental value in any democracy, as outlined in the Bill of Rights. Federal agencies possess documents on human rights violations abroad that are crucial for foreign authorities to investigate and prosecute. Federal agencies hold documents on gross human rights violations abroad needed by foreign authorities for investigation and prosecution, including cases involving US citizens. Requests for legal assistance, including document declassification, are received from foreign authorities, such as Guatemala, Honduras, and a Spanish court magistrate, Baltasar Garzon. The United States receives requests from foreign authorities for legal assistance on human rights violations, including document declassification. Recently, a Spanish court magistrate requested information on General Augusto Pinochet. The US follows procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders for declassification requests, reflecting its commitment to human rights protection and promotion nationally and internationally. The United States prioritizes protecting and promoting human rights nationally and internationally by strengthening declassification procedures, including the Freedom of Information Act. Expedient declassification of human rights documents in compliance with US security interests will enhance the rule of law and safeguard global human rights. The expedient declassification of human rights documents in compliance with US security interests will protect global human rights by strengthening the rule of law internationally, ensuring accountability of Federal agencies, and saving Government resources. The commitment to promoting human rights globally has led the United States to undertake diplomatic, economic, and military efforts to end human rights violations abroad. The United States is committed to promoting human rights and democracy globally, undertaking diplomatic, economic, and military efforts to end human rights violations abroad. This includes the involvement of numerous humanitarian organizations and citizens in promoting these values in foreign countries. Efforts are hindered if the cycle of impunity for human rights violations is not broken. The United States and its citizens support human rights and democracy globally. Efforts are hindered if impunity for human rights violations continues in foreign countries, leading to potential renewed US engagements. It is crucial for newly established democratic societies to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to ensure credibility. The United States emphasizes the importance of newly established democratic societies investigating and prosecuting human rights violations to end impunity. This can be achieved through truth commissions, human rights officers, or national investigations led by credible civil society sections. The US has a history of providing international leadership in this area. The United States has long provided international leadership to end impunity for human rights violations by supporting various war crimes tribunals and ratifying the Convention against Torture. The United States has ratified the Convention against Torture, obligating parties to provide assistance in criminal proceedings related to acts of torture. Additionally, as a member State of the Organization of American States, the US should follow recommendations to end impunity for human rights violations. The United States, as a member State of the Organization of American States, should provide all evidence necessary for proceedings related to acts of torture. It is recommended to adopt measures to ensure free access to information in cases of investigations into international crimes and serious human rights violations. The Guatemalan peace accords, supported by the United States, included an investigation by the Commission for the Historical Clarification of Human Rights Violations and Acts of Violence to establish criminal responsibility for international crimes and serious violations of human rights. The Commission for the Historical Clarification of Human Rights Violations in Guatemala recommended utilizing all resources to address unanswered questions about perpetrators and missing bodies. The Clarification Commission recommended using all resources to clarify the whereabouts of the disappeared and deliver remains to relatives. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project, was assassinated. Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project, was assassinated two days after presenting a parallel investigation in Guatemala. President Clinton condemned support for military forces involved in repression in a statement on March 10, 1999. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting documentation from the United States on human rights violations in Honduras since November 15, 1993. The National Commissioner for the Protection of Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting documentation from the United States on human rights violations since November 15, 1993, with some aspects still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by the US Government. "Agency" includes entities like the Department of State, Agency for International Development, Department of Defense, Central Intelligence Agency, and National. The curr_chunk discusses the entities involved in foreign intelligence and defines "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights." SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS REGARDING GUATEMALA AND HONDURAS. The Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records by agencies. Each agency must identify, review, and organize human rights records related to Guatemala and Honduras after 1944 for declassification and public disclosure within 30 days after review completion. The Act requires agencies to disclose human rights records related to Guatemala and Honduras after 1944 to the public within 30 days of review completion. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. GROUNDS FOR POSTPONEMENT OF PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF RECORDS. An agency may delay public disclosure of a human rights record if there is clear evidence that the threat to national security outweighs the public interest, such as revealing intelligence agents or sources. The gravity of the situation outweighs public interest, and disclosure could reveal sensitive intelligence information, including identities of agents or undisclosed methods that could interfere with intelligence activities. The disclosure of undisclosed sensitive information related to military defense, intelligence operations, or foreign relations of the United States could impair national security. Additionally, public disclosure of human rights records is also a concern. The public disclosure of human rights records could pose a risk to individuals who provided confidential information to the United States and may constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy outweighing public interest. The public disclosure of human rights records may constitute an invasion of personal privacy or compromise confidentiality agreements, outweighing public interest. The disclosure of human rights records may be postponed if it involves a Government agent, cooperating individual, or foreign government, and the harm outweighs public interest. Special treatment is given to information regarding intelligence assets of the United States Government. The term "intelligence asset" refers to a covert agent as defined in the National Security Act of 1947. When a US agency receives a request for human rights records from international entities or countries investigating violations, they must review and disclose the records according to the standards in the Act. SEC. 7. REVIEW OF DECISIONS TO WITHHOLD RECORDS. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone public disclosure of human rights records and directs disclosure unless clear evidence proves otherwise. The Appeals Panel directs disclosure of all human rights records unless clear evidence proves otherwise, allowing for postponement in certain cases. The Appeals Panel can postpone disclosure of a human rights record and determine alternative forms of disclosure in consultation with the agency. The agency is required to make alternative forms of disclosure as described in paragraph (3), which include disclosing a segregable portion of the human rights record, a substitute record, or a summary of the information. Additionally, the agency must notify of its determination. Upon completion of its review, the Appeals Panel notifies the agency head of its determination and publishes it in the Federal Register within 14 days. The Appeals Panel notifies the President of its determination within 14 days and publishes it in the Federal Register, including an explanation of the standards applied. The Appeals Panel must provide a written justification for its determination, including an explanation of the standards used. The President has the authority to review any decision made by the Appeals Panel based on set standards. The President has sole authority to review Appeals Panel determinations under this Act based on set standards, providing written certification within 30 days, including reasons for the decision. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification of the decision within 30 days, including reasons for the decision and the standards for postponing disclosure. The Appeals Panel will then publish the certification in the Federal Register. The Appeals Panel will publish in the Federal Register any unclassified written certification, statement, and materials from the President regarding the postponement of disclosure of a human rights record. SEC. 8. The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on the declassification of human rights records for other countries. The report will be made public. SEC. 9. Rules of Construction. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit the right to file a request with any executive agency under the Freedom of Information Act or seek judicial review. Judicial review is not precluded for final actions taken under this Act. SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. SEC. 10. CREATION OF POSITIONS. Two additional positions in the Appeals Panel will be created under this Act. The President will appoint individuals with substantial human rights expertise who are not US employees and meet security requirements. Recommendations for these positions will be sought from nongovernmental human rights organizations.
